description.plain:
Known across the pop culture spectrum as the “Queen of Pop” and “The Voice” for her mezzo-soprano octave, Whitney Elizabeth Houston left an indelible impression upon pop culture. She is one of the most successful artists of all time, with more than 200 million albums sold worldwide.

Born August 9, 1963, Houston grew up singing as part of the gospel choir at her local church. She was surrounded by powerful voices in her own family (mother Cissy Houston, cousin Dionne Warwick, godmother Darlene Love, honorary aunt Aretha Franklin). After working as a model and commercial actress in the early 1980s, Whitney was discovered during a New York City nightclub performance, which led to her signing a contract with Clive Davis at Arista Records. Whitney’s first song was a duet in 1984 with Teddy Pendergrass on “Hold Me.”

She released her self-titled début album the following year, which catapulted her into superstardom as the album topped the Billboard 200 for 14 non-consecutive weeks before becoming the top-selling album of 1986, eventually achieving diamond status in the US and selling over 22 million copies worldwide. The singles “Saving All My Love For You,” “How Will I Know,” and “Greatest Love of All” topped the Billboard Hot 100 and achieved platinum status. The music video for “How Will I Know” received heavy rotation on MTV, which was uncommon for Black women at the time. She took home the Best Female Pop Vocal Performance Grammy Award for “Saving” in 1986; her performance at the Grammys of “Saving” later won her an Emmy award. She also won seven American Music Awards between 1986 and 1987.

1987’s Whitney only furthered her initial success. The album produced four more consecutive #1 singles on the Billboard Hot 100–“I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me),” “Didn’t We Almost Have It All,” “So Emotional,” and “Where Do Broken Hearts Go”–giving her a record seven consecutive #1 pop singles. She won another Grammy Award in the Best Female Pop Vocal Performance category for “I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me),” which was an international hit, topping the pop charts in several countries as the album sold over 20 million copies worldwide.

While gaining the status as a “pop princess,” Whitney faced some criticism from the Black community, so she decided to work with producers L.A. Reid and Babyface on her third album, I’m Your Baby Tonight, which yielded two more #1 pop hits: “I’m Your Baby Tonight” and “All the Man That I Need.” In 1991, at Super Bowl XXV, Houston delivered arguably the greatest performance of the Star-Spangled Banner. The performance was sentimental as it occurred in the midst of the Persian Gulf War and a commercial single of the performance was produced, which reached the Top 20 on the Billboard Hot 100 as the single’s proceeds were donated to the American Red Cross Gulf Crisis Fund.

In 1992, Houston married R&B singer Bobby Brown and gave birth to their daughter Bobbi Kristina the following year. Whitney also pushed into the film industry in 1992 with her film The Bodyguard, which co-starred Kevin Costner. The film was a resounding success at the box office and its soundtrack–which featured Whitney’s signature song “I Will Always Love You”–sold 44 million units worldwide and brought Houston three Grammy awards, including Album of the Year.

In 1995, Houston starred in the film Waiting to Exhale with three other prominent black women, opening doors in the film industry for women of color. The Babyface-produced soundtrack was highly successful, giving her another #1 pop hit with the single “Exhale (Shoop Shoop)”. She also appeared in the movies The Preacher’s Wife and a revised version of Cinderella with singer Brandy.

Houston’s fourth album, My Love Is Your Love, was released in 1998 after an eight-year break from her previous studio album. In 1999, Whitney won an Academy Award for Best Original Song for her duet with Mariah Carey on the song “When You Believe” from The Prince of Egypt. Whitney would go on to release three more albums: Just Whitney (2002), One Wish: The Holiday Album (2003), and I Look to You (2009).

On February 11, 2012, Houston tragically passed away at the Beverly Hills Hotel days before the Grammy Awards ceremony, sending shockwaves through the general public and music community. She is one of the most celebrated artists in music history and awarded female entertainer of all time, winning over 400 awards, and acknowledged as a major influence on many R&B and pop singers who followed her.

songs.full_title: I Will Always Love You by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I Will Always Love You

description.plain:
“I Will Always Love You” was covered by Whitney Houston and recorded for her 1992 film The Bodyguard. The song was originally written by Dolly Parton and released on June 6, 1974 as the second single from her thirteenth solo studio album, Jolene.

Houston’s cover has since become one of the best-selling singles of all time and contributed to The Bodyguard being the top-selling soundtrack of all time. Kevin Costner, Houston’s male opposite and one of the film’s co-producers, is actually responsible for suggesting this song for Houston to cover in the film’s first track release. He brought the original song to composer David Foster, who rearranged it as a pop ballad for Houston.

It topped the Billboard Hot 100 for fourteen consecutive weeks; at the time, this was a record for longest number one. It also reached #3 on the Hot 100 after Houston’s death in 2012.

songs.full_title: I Have Nothing by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I Have Nothing

description.plain:
“I Have Nothing” is the third single from the soundtrack to The Bodyguard. It was written by David Foster & Linda Thompson.

The song peaked at #4 on the Billboard Hot 100, #4 on Billboard’s Hot R&B Singles chart and topped Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart. It also topped the RPM chart in Canada.

It was nominated for Best Original Song at the 1993 Academy Awards, a Grammy for Best Song Written Specifically for a Motion Picture or Television and a Soul Train Music Award for Best R&B Single, Female.

songs.full_title: Greatest Love of All by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Greatest Love of All

description.plain:
“Greatest Love of All” was written by Michael Masser & the late Linda Creed, who wrote the song during her struggle with breast cancer.

The song was originally in 1977 by George Benson for the Muhammad Ali biopic “The Greatest.”

Whitney covered the song for her 1985 self-titled debut album.

Originally, Clive Davis didn’t want Whitney to record the song for the album, but eventually gave in after being persuaded by Michael Masser and Whitney.

The song became a hit, topping the Billboard Hot 100, Hot Black Singles and adult contemporary charts in 1986. The song also topped the charts in Australia and Canada.

It was certified Gold in the U.S. and Canada & certified Silver in the U.K.

“Greatest Love of All” won the American Music Award for “Favorite Soul/R&B Video.” It was also nominated for a Grammy Award for “Record of the Year” and a Soul Train Music Award for “Single of the Year.”

songs.lyrics:
I believe the children are our future
Teach them well and let them lead the way
Show them all the beauty they possess inside
Give them a sense of pride to make it easier
Let the children's laughter remind us how we used to be
Everybody's searching for a hero
People need someone to look up to
I never found anyone who fulfilled my needs
A lonely place to be
And so I learned to depend on me

I decided long ago
Never to walk in anyone's shadows
If I fail, if I succeed
At least I'll live as I believe
No matter what they take from me
They can't take away my dignity

Because the greatest love of all
Is happening to me
I found the greatest love of all
Inside of me
The greatest love of all
Is easy to achieve
Learning to love yourself
It is the greatest love of all

Because the greatest love of all
Is happening to me
I found the greatest love of all
Inside of me
The greatest love of all
Is easy to achieve
Learning to love yourself
It is the greatest love of all

And if, by chance, that special place
That you've been dreaming of
Leads you to a lonely place
Find your strength in love

songs.full_title: I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me) by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)
songs.title_with_featured: I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)

description.plain:
Whitney Houston’s 1987 single “I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)” was her biggest hit until “I Will Always Love You,” five years later.

The story behind the song belongs to its songwriters—George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam of the band Boy Meets Girl. Merrill and Rubicam first worked with Whitney on her 1985#1  hit “How Will I Know.” Thanks to the success of “How Will I Know,” legendary music executive Clive Davis asked them to write another song for Whitney.

In The Billboard Book of Number One Hits, Rubicam recalled being inspired to write a song after she and Merrill watched Whitney perform at an outdoor venue.

She had just finished singing ‘How Will I Know’ and we just happened to look up while people were clapping and a star was falling.
We both saw it, so I pulled out my little notepad and wrote ‘Waiting for a Star to Fall’ and then later wrote a song around it. We sent it off to her and they passed on it.

Rubicam recalled writing this song:

I pictured somebody single wishing that they could find that special person for themselves. It wasn’t, ‘I wanna go down the disco and dance.’ It was, ‘I wanna do that dance of life with somebody.’ That was the thought behind the song. We sent our demo version off to Clive Davis and he loved it.

But not everyone loved their version—producer Narada Michael Walden didn’t think it fit for Whitney. Walden said, “It reminded me of a rodeo song with Olivia Newton-John singing.”

I love Olivia Newton-John, but for Whitney Houston it didn’t seem right. I felt the song needed a much more funkier feel.
I slept, dreaming about it, woke up in the morning thinking about it, wondering what am I gonna do with this dance song.
So, we just jumped in the water and lo and behold a magic record was born, Houston just knocked it out and then I knew we had a good record.

Merrill and Rubicam didn’t get to hear the finished song until the album was done, when Clive Davis invited them to an album listening party, where he told them it would be the album’s first single and predicted it would go #1.

The song became a Houston’s fourth #1 hit in the United States—it went #1 in 14 countries.

songs.full_title: How Will I Know by Whitney Houston
songs.title: How Will I Know

description.plain:
“How Will I Know"is the third single from Whitney Houston’s 1985 self-titled debut album.

It was written by George Merrill, Shannon Rubicam and Narada Michael Walden (who also produced the song).

The song was originally meant for Janet Jackson, but her management declined because they felt it was too weak in comparison to her other material.

Whitney’s mother, Cissy Houston was supposed to provide backup vocals on the song, but Whitney was implored by Clive Davis to sing the backup vocals herself.

“How Will I Know” topped the Billboard Hot 100, Hot Black Singles and Adult Contemporary chart. It also topped the charts in Canada as well.

It was certified Gold in the United States and Canada.

The song’s music video received heavy airplay on MTV and won an MTV Video Music Award for Best Female Video.

songs.full_title: Saving All My Love For You by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Saving All My Love For You
songs.title_with_featured: Saving All My Love For You

description.plain:
“Saving All My Love for You” is a song written by Michael Masser and Gerry Goffin with arrangement by Gene Page. It was originally a minor hit for Marilyn McCoo and Billy Davis Jr. in 1978 on their album Marilyn & Billy (although Davis’ voice was not heard on their version).



Whitney Houston released her cover of this song as the second single from her self-titled debut album. The song topped Billboard Hot 100, becoming Houston’s first #1 on the chart. The song has sold over 3 million copies worldwide.

songs.full_title: It's Not Right, But It's Okay by Whitney Houston
songs.title: It’s Not Right, But It’s Okay
songs.title_with_featured: It's Not Right, But It's Okay

description.plain:
It’s Not Right, But It’s Okay is the third single of off Whitney Houston’s fourth studio album My Love Is Your Love (1998).

In this song produced by Rodney Jerkins, Houston continues to prove that she can hang with the kids on the street. The diva is placed at the center of a jittery funk beat that suits the tension of the lyrics. Houston plays the emancipated woman to the hilt here, snarling through the song’s “I’m gonna make it anyway” message with a white-knuckled gusto that she hadn’t displayed in ages.

Loyalists yearning for one of the singer’s patented power ballads will be disappointed at first, though they will likely find solace in Jerkins' Smooth remix, which reinvents the tune as a languid jeep cruiser. Everyone else, however, should find this single as appealing and refreshing as it is timely and competitive.

The song peaked at #4 on the US Billboard Hot 100 singles chart on July 3, 1999. The single also peaked at #1 on Billboard‍'​s Hot Dance Music/Club Play chart, #7 on the top 100 Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks chart, and was certified Platinum by the RIAA.

It also reached #3 in Canada and the United Kingdom — in March 1999 — where it stayed in the chart for 15 weeks, being a hugely popular radio hit in that country.

songs.full_title: Run to You by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Run to You

description.plain:
“Run to You” is the fourth single from the soundtrack to “The Bodyguard.” It was written by Jud Friedman & Allan Rich.

The song was originally writtten as a breakup song, but Mick Jackson (the director of “The Bodyguard”) said that he would rather have it as a love song, so the song was re-written, but the song title stayed the same.

“Run to You” peaked at #31 on the Billboard Hot 100 and Hot R&B Singles chart & #10 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart.

songs.full_title: My Love is Your Love by Whitney Houston
songs.title: My Love is Your Love

description.plain:
“My Love Is Your Love” is the fourth and title single released from R&B superstar Whitney Houston’s fourth studio album. The Wyclef Jean-helmed ballad is anchored by beat beats and a steady bassline not unlike those in his own hit song “Guantanamera”.



The song features doting and precocious vocal cameos from Houston’s daughter Bobbi Kristina Brown throughout. The endearing quality their pairing has been replaced with a more somber feeling since Whitney died in 2012 and three years later, her daughter Bobbi Kristina Brown as well under eerily similar circumstances. Wyclef Jean reflects on the recording process with Whitney and Bobbi Kristina in an interview with Rolling Stone magazine:

The greatest memory for me was, as hard as she was working, she had her daughter in the studio. She was five or six. Do you know how hard it is to be recording and your kid’s there? But when it came to her daughter, the rest of the world didn’t exist. She was recording one of her biggest comeback records ever – and it really wasn’t about the comeback record. It was about making sure that her daughter was there with her, experiencing what she was experiencing. This is the Whitney that I know.

In the same interview, Wyclef describes a friendship that spawned from their work. “I was having so much fun with Whitney – the Whitney from Newark, New Jersey – that I don’t really know when we got the song done.” Whitney validated that friendship by making a guest appearance on Wyclef’s next album The Ecleftic: 2 Sides II a Book resinging “My Love Is Your Love” a capella with altered lyrics on the track “Whitney Houston Dub Plate.”

Wyclef said that Bobby Brown did background vocals for this song and more facts on Run That Back | EP 1. “Lena Waithe Hears Unreleased Whitney Houston Recording”, premiered Aug 21, 2020

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0QO8KWD_5Ds&ab_channel=WyclefJean

description.plain:
“I’m Your Baby Tonight” is the title song from Whitney Houston’s 1990 third album. It was written & produced by L.A. Reid and Babyface.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 and Hot Black Singles chart. It also topped the charts in Italy.

It was also certified Gold by the RIAA.

songs.full_title: Heartbreak Hotel by Whitney Houston (Ft. Faith Evans & Kelly Price)
songs.title: Heartbreak Hotel
songs.title_with_featured: Heartbreak Hotel (Ft. Faith Evans & Kelly Price)

description.plain:
Released on December 15, 1998 as the second single from [My Love Is Your Love], “Heartbreak Hotel” was the first introduction to Whitney’s new more Urban-oriented sound and the first non-soundtrack single she had released in years.

The song and accompanying video featured R&B singers Kelly Price and Faith Evans on vocals.  It peaked at #1 on the Billboard R&B chart and #2 on the Hot 100.



“Heartbreak Hotel” was originally offered to girl group TLC
for their third studio album “FanMail. The group passed on it, a move that was publicly critized my member Lisa ‘Left Eye’ Lopes after it became a massive hit for Whitney.

songs.full_title: Where Do Broken Hearts Go by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Where Do Broken Hearts Go

description.plain:
“Where Do Broken Hearts Go” is the fourth single from Whitney Houston’s sophomore album Whitney.

At first, Whitney didn’t want to record the song because she felt that there wasn’t a special message to convey, but Clive Davis was able to convince her that the song would become number-one if she recorded it.

And Clive was right.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100, becoming Whitney’s seventh #1 song and Adult Contemporary chart.

songs.full_title: So Emotional by Whitney Houston
songs.title: So Emotional

description.plain:
So Emotional is the third single from Whitney Houston’s sophomore album. It was written by Billy Steinberg & Tom Kelly and produced by Narada Michael Walden.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 and Hot Dance Music\Club Play Songs chart in 1988. It also peaked at #5 on Billboard’s Hot Black Singles chart and #8 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart. It was certified Gold by the RIAA.

In the United Kingdom, it was remixed by Shep Pettibone. The remixed version peaked at #5 on the U.K. Singles chart and was certified Silver by the BPI.

songs.full_title: All The Man That I Need by Whitney Houston
songs.title: All The Man That I Need
songs.title_with_featured: All The Man That I Need

description.plain:
“All The Man That I Need” was written by Dean Pitchford and Michael Gore. It was first recorded as “All The Man I Need” by Linda Clifford in 1982.

It was also recorded by Sister Sledge in 1982 as well, but their version peaked at #45 on Billboard’s Hot Soul Singles chart.

Whitney Houston covered the song for her third album “I’m Your Baby Tonight”.

Her version topped the Billboard Hot 100, Hot R&B Singles and Adult Contemporary chart. It also topped the RPM chart in Canada. It was certified Gold by the RIAA in the United States.

The song was nominated for a Grammy for “Best Pop Vocal Performance, Female” and a Soul Train Music Award for “Best R&B\Soul Single, Female”.

e lead single from the soundtrack to the 1995 film “Waiting to Exhale”. It was written & produced by Babyface.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 and Hot R&B Singles chart. It also peaked at #5 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart. It also topped the charts in Canada and Spain.

It was certified Platinum by the RIAA. It also won a Grammy in 1997 for Best R&B Song.

description.plain:
Didn’t We Almost Have It All is the second single from Whitney Houston’s sophomore album Whitney. It was written by Michael Masser & Will Jennings.

The song topped the Billboard Hot 100 and Adult Contemporary chart. It also peaked at #2 on Billboard’s Hot Black Singles chart in 1987.

It was nominated for a Grammy for “Song of the Year.”

songs.full_title: You Give Good Love by Whitney Houston
songs.title: You Give Good Love

description.plain:
You Give Good Love is the lead single from Whitney Houston’s 1985 self-titled debut album.

The song was written by La La and produced by Kashif.

After La La sent Kashif a copy of the song (which was originally offered to Roberta Flack), Kashif thought that the song would be a better fit for Whitney & told Arista Records that he was interested in recording the song with her.

The song peaked at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, #4 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart and topped Billboard’s Hot Black Singles chart for a week in May of 1985.

It won an American Music Award for “Favorite Soul\R&B Single” and was nominated for two Grammy Awards: “Best R&B Song” & “Best R&B Vocal Performance, Female”.

songs.full_title: Queen of the Night by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Queen of the Night

description.plain:
“Queen of the Night” was the single released from the soundtrack to The Bodyguard. It was written by Whitney, L.A. Reid, Babyface, and Daryl Simmons.

The song wasn’t released as a single in America, but managed to peak at #36 on Billboard’s Hot 100 Airplay chart, #47 on Billboard’s R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart and topped Billboard’s Hot Dance Music/Club Play Songs chart for a week in January of 1994.

It didn’t chart on the Billboard Hot 100 because at the time, Billboard magazine rules stated that a song with no commercial single available couldn’t chart on the Hot 100.

songs.full_title: I Didn't Know My Own Strength by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I Didn’t Know My Own Strength
songs.title_with_featured: I Didn't Know My Own Strength

description.plain:
Whitney Houston’s seventh studio album, I Look to You, saw a more outspoken and courageous Whitney. SongFacts.com explains that

[d]uring the 2000s, Houston experienced considerable personal and professional turmoil, including the breakdown of her marriage to [[Bobby Brown and media speculation about drug use. This song talks about how she survived her darkest hour and picked herself up.

The song was written by Diane Warren, who is a Grammmy award winning songwriter, her most recent nom being the title track of the Silver Linings Playbook official soundtrack.

songs.full_title: The Star Spangled Banner by Whitney Houston (Ft. The Florida Orchestra)
songs.title: The Star Spangled Banner
songs.title_with_featured: The Star Spangled Banner (Ft. The Florida Orchestra)

description.plain:
Houston’s version of the American National Anthem that she performed at the XXV Superbowl in 1991 at the Tampa Stadium is often considered one of the greatest National Anthem renditions in history. It was later released as a charity single for soldiers in the Persian Gulf Wars. It later became RIAA certified Platinum as a single.

Many critics deemed Houston’s performance as one of the greatest live performances she had ever delivered in her career.

songs.full_title: Higher Love by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Higher Love

description.plain:
“Higher Love” is one of 2 bonus tracks on the Japanese release of Whitney Houston’s 3rd album, “I’m Your Baby Tonight”.

It is a cover of the song of the same name by Steve Winwood. It was removed from the American album because Clive Davis didn’t want Whitney to be looked at as a covers artist since several of her other songs were covers.
In 2019, Seven years after Whitney’s passing, producer Kygo released a remix of the song that does not include the bridge.

songs.full_title: Miracle by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Miracle

description.plain:
“Miracle” is the third single from Whitney Houston’s third album “I’m Your Baby Tonight.” It was written by L.A. Reid & Babyface.

According to Whitney in an interview with Jet Magazine in their June 14, 1991 issue, she didn’t intend for the song or the music video to be about abortion, stating:

I think about the air we breathe, the earth we live on. I think about our children. I think about a lot of things, things God put here for us to have, things that we need and we take for granted. I think all of these things are miracles and I think we should try to take better care of them."

The song peaked at #9 on the Billboard Hot 100, #2 on Billboard’s Hot R&B Singles chart and #4 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart in 1991.

songs.full_title: I Know Him So Well by Whitney Houston (Ft. Cissy Houston)
songs.title: I Know Him So Well
songs.title_with_featured: I Know Him So Well (Ft. Cissy Houston)

description.plain:
“I Know Him So Well” was written by Tim Rice, Benny Andersson and Bjorn Uvaeus for the musical “Chess.”

Whitney and her mother Cissy covered the song for Whitney’s 1987 sophomore album “Whitney.” It was released as the final single from the album.

Whitney & Cissy’s version of the song peaked at #14 on the Dutch Top 40 in the Netherlands and #46 on the Media Control Charts in Germany in 1988.

Unlike Whitney’s previous singles from the album, “I Know Him So Well” wasn’t heavily promoted.

description.plain: The fifth and final single off her album My Love Is Your Love, “I Learned From The Best” is a heartbroken ballad about how she knows how to break hearts since he broke hers. The song peaked at #27 on the Billboard Hot 100 and certified Gold by the RIAA.

description.plain:
“My Name Is Not Susan” was the fourth single from Whitney Houston’s third album “I’m Your Baby Tonight.” It was written by Eric Foster White & produced by L.A. Reid and Babyface.

The song peaked at #20 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #8 on Billboard’s Hot R&B Singles chart in 1991.

songs.full_title: His Eye Is On The Sparrow by Whitney Houston
songs.title: His Eye Is On The Sparrow
songs.title_with_featured: His Eye Is On The Sparrow

description.plain: His Eye Is On The Sparrow is the second single from the motion picture soundtrack, It was sung by the late Whitney Houston and was released on June 8, 2012 3 months after she passed away. You can’t help but notice how ragged her voice sounds, but she still had just enough vocal technique left to sing this uplifting song.

songs.full_title: Million Dollar Bill by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Million Dollar Bill

description.plain:
Million Dollar Bill is the first song and a future single by Whitney Houston from her long awaited sixth studio album, “I Look to You“.
The song was written by Alicia Keys after the singer-songwriter personally asked Davis if she could make a contribution to the album. The song was produced by rapper Swizz Beatz but critics commented that it does not sound like a typical “Swizzy” production its more old-school R&B but definitely is not an attempt to create a club banger.

songs.full_title: If I Told You That (Duet) by Whitney Houston (Ft. George Michael)
songs.title: If I Told You That (Duet)
songs.title_with_featured: If I Told You That (Duet) (Ft. George Michael)

description.plain:
If I Told You That was first released in 1998 on Whitney’s My Love is Your Love album, originally recorded solo.
This duet version with George Michael, the more recognized version of the track, was conceptualized and recorded in March 2000, to be featured on (and released as the second single from) ‘Whitney: The Greatest Hits’ in May. It became a hit internationally, scoring a number 1 hit in Iceland and Poland; and a top 10 charting in the UK and Italy.

songs.full_title: I Belong To You by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I Belong To You

description.plain:
“I Belong to You” is the fifth single from Whitney Houston’s third album “I’m Your Baby Tonight.” It was written by Franne Golde & Derek Bramble and produced by Narada Michael Walden.

The song peaked at #10 on Billboard’s Hot R&B Singles chart in 1991 and was nominated for a Grammy Award for “Best Female R&B Vocal Performance.”

songs.full_title: Just the Lonely Talking Again by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Just the Lonely Talking Again

description.plain:
This is one of Whitney’s greatest songs ever! She made The Manhattans song her song. The song is similar to The Manhattans version but Whitney is singing from a woman’s point of view.
I feel like everybody slept on this song right here. The beat is so smooth and her voice makes this a masterpiece.

This was also a cover of The Manhattans song that came out in 1983 on there album Right By Your Side!

 The song is about Whitney seeking confirmation from a guy who she has recently had history with. She intrigued to know basically what are the two gonna be.

songs.full_title: We Didn't Know by Whitney Houston (Ft. Stevie Wonder)
songs.title: We Didn’t Know

description.plain:
We Didn’t Know is the last single from Whitney Houston’s third album I’m Your Baby Tonight. It featured Stevie Wonder (who wrote & co-produced the song).

The song peaked at #20 on Billboard’s Hot R&B Singles chart in 1992.

songs.full_title: Take Good Care of My Heart by Whitney Houston (Ft. Jermaine Jackson)
songs.title: Take Good Care of My Heart
songs.title_with_featured: Take Good Care of My Heart (Ft. Jermaine Jackson)

description.plain:
The connection happend after Jermaine seen young Whitney singing on the Marv Griffen Show in 1983. After seeing that Jermaine was impressed and called Clive Davis wanting to work with Whitney.



It made sense of the connection due to them both being on the same label as well. The two had a very good blend and musical chemistry. It was even rumored that the two were dating around this time.

 The song was first released on Jermaine Jackson’s Dynamite album in 1984, a year before Whitney’s album. This would be the first time the world would hear of Whitney would be in 1984 on Jermaine’s album.

https://youtu.be/TWDlnu_HvKQ?t=18s

songs.full_title: Fine by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Fine

description.plain:
“Fine” was a single released from Whitney Houston’s first compilation album Whitney: The Greatest Hits. Though a music video accompanied the song, it only reached #51 on the R&B charts. In some markets, it was released as a double-A-side single along with the George Michael duet “If I Told You That.”

“Fine” sees Whitney occupying her lower register for most of the song and turning out midtempo, hip-hop influenced party music only vaguely reminiscent of her Wyclef Jean-produced “My Love Is Your Love” with its track’s bassy tones and tight high end accents.

description.plain: “In My Buissness” is the sixth song on Whitney’s 1998 album My Love Is your Love. The song features legendary artist Missy Elliot who also wrote and produced the song. The song is about nosy people that think they know about her relationship when they really don’t.

songs.full_title: Get It Back by Whitney Houston
songs.title: Get It Back

description.plain: This bouncy, Darkchild-produced track was recorded in October 1998 for Whitney’s third studio album My Love Is Your Love. Lyrically, it speaks of a woman being reminiscent of a love that a man no longer pays attention to, and wishing that she could retrieve the times back when this man regarded her and their relationship highly.

songs.full_title: I'm Knockin by Whitney Houston
songs.title: I’m Knockin

description.plain:
“I’m Knockin” is the 11th track on Whitney’s third album I’m Your Baby Tonight.“ The song was written by Bebe Winans and produced by Rickey Minor & Whitney herself. This was Whitney’s first experience with producing.



“Seeing exactly what goes into producing and i’m telling you its more than a notion to be a producer. So much work goes into that, I praise producers on what they do.”

 -Whitney on her first production experience.

“Seeing exactly what goes into producing and i’m telling you its more than a notion to be a producer. So much work goes into that, I praise producers on what they do.”

 -Whitney on her first production experience.

songs.lyrics:
Verse 1
I believe the children are our future
Teach them well and let them lead the way
Show them all the beauty they possess inside
Give them a sense of pride to make it easier
Let the children's laughter remind us how we used to be
Everybody's searching for a hero
People need someone to look up to
I never found anyone who fulfilled my needs
A lonely place to be
And so I learned to depend on me
Chorus
I decided long ago
Never to walk in anyone's shadows
If I fail, if I succeed
At least I'll live as I believe
No matter what they take from me
They can't take away my dignity
Because the greatest love of all
Is happening to me
I found the greatest love of all
Inside of me
The greatest love of all
Is easy to achieve
Learning to love yourself
It is the greatest love of all
Verse 2
I believe the children are our future
Teach them well and let them lead the way
Show them all the beauty they possess inside
Give them a sense of pride to make it easier
Let the children's laughter remind us how we used to be
Chorus
I decided long ago, never to walk in anyone's shadows
If I fail, if I succeed
At least I'll live as I believe
No matter what they take from me
They can't take away my dignity
Because the greatest love of all
Is happening to me
I found the greatest love of all
Inside of me
The greatest love of all
Is easy to achieve
Learning to love yourself
It is the greatest love of all
Verse 3
And if, by chance, that special place
That you've been dreaming of
Leads you to a lonely place
Find your strength in love
